classmethod compare_configs(first, second, difference_allowed=None, deviation_allowed=None)[source]¶

Compares 2 configuration dicts. Returns a dict of the difference in the 2 dicts

@param first: First dict @param second: Second dict @param deviation_allowed: Dict of fields where a deviation is allowed.

Key is fieldname, value is deviation allowed in percent

@param difference_allowed: Dict of fields where a difference is allowed

Key is fieldname, value is difference allowed in count

@return: dict of difference between first and second

classmethod compare_ethtool_output(ethtool1, ethtool2, keytosearch, report='error', optional_field=False)[source]¶
classmethod diff_configs(first, second, difference_allowed=None, deviation_allowed=None, parents=None, diffs=None)[source]¶

Compares 2 configuration dicts. Returns a list of the difference in the 2 dicts This routine is recursive for nested dictionaries.

@param first: First dict @param second: Second dict

@param deviation_allowed: Dict of fields where a deviation is allowed.

Key is fieldname, value is deviation allowed in percent

@param difference_allowed: Dict of fields where a difference is allowed

Key is fieldname, value is difference allowed in count

@param - (list) parents - the nested dictionary names above us. @params - (list) diffs - the list of diffs we’ve found already. @return: dict of difference between first and second or a list of them

if we found more than 1.

classmethod fbcode_relative_path(path)[source]¶

Given the file path of a havoc test/library, return the path relative to fbcode. This takes care of most autotest and autoval test paths, but will fail if a test is called with a relative path such as “./iperf.py”

classmethod validate_empty_diff(diff, msg, raise_on_fail=True, log_on_pass=True)[source]¶

Validates that the diff passed in is empty. Diff has to have the format as created by the compare_configs method in this module. Example:

diff = AutovalUtils.compare_configs(before_dict, after_dict) self.validate_empty_diff(diff, “Check for no diff”)

Creates a separate step for each difference (if any)

havoc.autotest_testfiles.validation_utils.lib.autoval_thread module¶

class havoc.autotest_testfiles.validation_utils.lib.autoval_thread.AutovalThread(exception_queue, target, *args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: threading.Thread

__init__(exception_queue, target, *args, **kwargs)[source]¶

This constructor should always be called with keyword arguments. Arguments are:

group should be None; reserved for future extension when a ThreadGroup class is implemented.

target is the callable object to be invoked by the run() method. Defaults to None, meaning nothing is called.

name is the thread name. By default, a unique name is constructed of the form “Thread-N” where N is a small decimal number.

args is the argument tuple for the target invocation. Defaults to ().

kwargs is a dictionary of keyword arguments for the target invocation. Defaults to {}.

If a subclass overrides the constructor, it must make sure to invoke the base class constructor (Thread.__init__()) before doing anything else to the thread.

run()[source]¶

Method representing the thread’s activity.

You may override this method in a subclass. The standard run() method invokes the callable object passed to the object’s constructor as the target argument, if any, with sequential and keyword arguments taken from the args and kwargs arguments, respectively.

Bases: object

static _get_storage_devices(ssd_only=0, hdd_only=0, power_on_all_slots=False)[source]¶
Case 1:

Returns all storage devices discoved using the below rules Step 1: Check if there is I/O controller/Raid controller for the

storage devices Megacli/fbjbod/array-controller based on the type of controller and get the external devices from them

Step 2: If there Is no controller get the block-devices from lsblk and

Identify the bootdrive remove remove from list

Step 3: If there is a call for ssd/hdd devices exclusively we will

filter only the hdd/ssd from the device list obtained

Case 2:

Check for all block devices identified using lsblk command and remove boot drive from the list and filter for SSD/HDD if user specifies

static create_partition(device, part_num=None, start_pct=None, end_pct=None, gpt=False, script=False, script_args='')[source]¶

Creates a partition using the parted utility. @param device: Device on which to create partition @part_num: Number of partition (see P* in example below) @start_pct: Start offset in percentage @end_pct: End offset in percentage @gpt: See to True to create GPT @script: Run everything that follows as a script

Example use case: parted -a optimal /dev/sds mktable gpt –script mkpart P1 0% 5% parted -a optimal /dev/sds –script mkpart P2 5% 20% parted -a optimal /dev/sds –script mkpart P3 20% 100% parted -s /dev/nvme0n1 unit b mkpart primary 128

havoc.autotest_testfiles.validation_utils.lib.fbjbod_utils._run(cmd, timeout=300)[source]¶

class havoc.autotest_testfiles.validation_utils.lib.pynvml._PrintableStructure[source]¶

Bases: _ctypes.Structure

Abstract class that produces nicer __str__ output than ctypes.Structure. e.g. instead of:

>>> print str(obj)
<class_name object at 0x7fdf82fef9e0>
this class will print

class_name(field_name: formatted_value, field_name: formatted_value)

_fmt_ dictionary of <str _field_ name> -> <str format> e.g. class that has _field_ ‘hex_value’, c_uint could be formatted with

_fmt_ = {“hex_value” : “%08X”}

to produce nicer output. Default fomratting string for all fields can be set with key “<default>” like:

_fmt_ = {“<default>” : “%d MHz”} # e.g all values are numbers in MHz.

If not set it’s assumed to be just “%s”

Exact format of returned str from this class is subject to change in the future.

havoc.autotest_testfiles.validation_utils.lib.pynvml._extractNVMLErrorsAsClasses()[source]¶

Generates a hierarchy of classes on top of NVMLError class.

Each NVML Error gets a new NVMLError subclass. This way try,except blocks can filter appropriate exceptions more easily.

NVMLError is a parent class. Each NVML_ERROR_* gets it’s own subclass. e.g. NVML_ERROR_ALREADY_INITIALIZED will be turned into NVMLError_AlreadyInitialized

static scsi_read_blocks(device, skip, count, bs)[source]¶

Read blocks of data continually from same offset(skip). count: number of blocks bs: size (in bytes) of each block read

static scsi_read_capacity(device)[source]¶

This command is to fetch the number of blocks (and block size) from the DEVICE.

static scsi_read_long(device, lba, out_file, xfer_len)[source]¶

Send SCSI READ LONG command to DEVICE. The read buffer is placed in out_file (if given). The data returned includes the logical block data (typically 512 bytes for a disk) plus ECC information (whose format is proprietary) plus optionally other proprietary data. lba: logical block address of the sector to read xfer_len: byte transfer length

static scsi_write_long(device, lba, in_file, xfer_len)[source]¶

Send the SCSI WRITE LONG command to DEVICE. The buffer to be written to the DEVICE is filled with 0xff bytes or read from the in_file. This utility can be used to generate a MEDIUM ERROR at a specific logical block address. lba: logical block address of the sector to read xfer_len: byte transfer length

static scsi_write_same(device, lba, num, xfer_len)[source]¶

Send the SCSI WRITE SAME command to DEVICE. This command writes the given block NUM times to consecutive blocks on the DEVICE starting at logical block address LBA.

dut_logdir –> Log dir at DUT and achieve at the end the test. Used to

store critical data on the test server during test.

control_server_logdir –> Log dir at control server and achieve at the

end the test. store any critical data on the control server.

control_server_tmpdir –> tmp dir at control server and deleted at the

end the of the test. store non critical data on the control server.

the test.

static get_test_memory(host, mem_perc, total_mem=True)[source]¶

Returns a percentage of the total free memory in MB using free -m based on the “memory_perc” argument. If total_mem is specified returns the percentage of the “total” column, otherwise percentage of the “free” column ‘free -m’ output:-

total used free shared buff/cache available

Mem: 57244 5618 1522 253 50103 49809

havoc.autotest_testfiles.validation_utils.lib.system_config_info.data_str_to_dict(data_str, prefix)[source]¶

Transforms data_str into a dictionary by looking for lines separated by the “:” character. Adds an optional prefix if passed in. Adds a counter if multiple lines with same entry are detected (_1, _2, …) Example with “mc” prefix: Transforms this line: Firmware Revision : 2.07 Into this dictionary entry: “mc_firmware_revision”: “2.07”

havoc.autotest_testfiles.validation_utils.lib.system_config_info.get_biosinfo()[source]¶

Returns a dictionary of all bios/me/bmc/cpld/vr/fsc information. (bios vendor, bios version, bios release, me version, fsc version)

havoc.autotest_testfiles.validation_utils.lib.system_config_info.get_bootdriveinfo()[source]¶

Returns a dictionary of boot drive information. (capacity, hw configuration, partition inf) Boot drive may be sda or nvme (flash)

havoc.autotest_testfiles.validation_utils.lib.system_config_info.normalize_keys(key_list, normalization, config_dict)[source]¶

Normalizes all ‘config_dict’ keys specified in key_list using the normalization dictionary which contains a regular expression that if matched is replaced with a normalized string.

havoc.autotest_testfiles.validation_utils.lib.system_config_info.parse_table(text)[source]¶

Parse column data from a table. Example: table = parse_table( ‘Node SN Model —————- ——————– —————————————- /dev/nvme0n1 FI5BQ00851CY6BI03 HFS256GD9MNC-5310A /dev/nvme0n2 FI5BQ00851CY6BI04 HFS256GD9MNC-5310B ‘) table[0][‘node’] = ‘/dev/nvme0n1’ table[1][‘sn’] = ‘FI5BQ00851CY6BI04’
